data.text:
For long rides I use my mtn bike pack. Have tried several packs and this one is by far the most comfortable because you can get the ‚Äúfit‚Äù just right. https://www.gregorypacks.com/packs-bags/hydration-packs/endo-15-3d-hydro-91650XXXX.html?dwvar_91650XXXX_color=Horizon%20Blue&cgidmaster=packs-activities-mountain-biking
Endo 15 3D-Hydro
gregorypacks.com

data.text: 2-3 liter Camelbak bladders 1.5 liter Nalgene bottles
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text:
Edit: I do not like wearing packs, the added weight after 8+hours in the saddle many days in a row is noticeable. I suggest trying CrankTank3 or 4 üëçüëç Link to the 3 below. I've also tried the 1.5L Apidura bladder in a frame bag. It was easy to use, although less capacity than the CrankTank3. I found the weight of it pulled the bags zipper apart. This may be solved by longer straps for the toptube, which I didn't have at the time, but longer straps may have allowed the frame bag to settle farther down, reducing or removing stress on the frame bag zipper. https://adventurehydration.com/product/water-storage-solutions-for-bikepackers-adventure-and-touring-cyclists-cranktank3/
CRANKTANK3 Kit - Adventure Hydration
adventurehydration.com
data.author: Darcy Therien

data.text: Couldn't agree more re Cranktank (3 in my case) Having just completed 3000km Tour Aotearoa, this proved to be the perfect solution for this Camelbak devotee needing secure and plentiful water capacity but off my back!
data.author: Alastair Palmer

data.text: , that's good to know! I haven't had an opportunity to use it on a lonnnggg trip yet. Any other feedback, good, bad or ugly?
data.author: Darcy Therien

data.text: Two of us did TA, both with Cranktank 3, and both had entirely positive experience. Filling it on the bike is straightforward but removing it from frame is easy. Hose/cap connection is a wee bit fiddly and should be given a light touch (although Andrew from Adventure Hydration says spout was reinforced during product development) Does require stronger suck than I'm used to with Camelbak, but that's physics! Not an issue in practical usage, and bite valve works well keeping fluid at mouthpiece. Sloshing of fluid in reservoir is audible but otherwise imperceptible. Maximizes use of that frame space relative to bottle/cage setup, keeps weight as low as possible, and I didn't see any dislodged Cranktanks littering the sides of the track! The number of positive comments and enquiries we had from fellow TA-rs adds more objective recommendation!
data.author: Alastair Palmer
Judi Schwandt

What came to mind for me were the oversized h2o cages that will hold maligned bottles or 2l pop bottles. Here‚Äôs the link I discovered with lots of options for touring. https://bikepacking.com/index/oversized-bottle-cages-for-bike-touring/
